title: Tinnitus in a Case of Meniereâ€™s Disease
chief_complaint: I have a constant ringing in my right ear and I've had terrible dizziness and hearing loss that started after my weight loss surgery. The noise is unbearable, and I feel helpless; I just want a cure.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden hearing loss, vertigo, and tinnitus occurred following significant weight loss after lap band surgery.
problem_summary.course: One year later, diagnosed with Meniere's disease (MD). Vestibular symptoms burned out, but right ear hearing worsened and tinnitus became severe, leading to suicidal ideation and psychiatric admission.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral hearing loss, worse in the right ear.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Vertigo with emesis (resolved), severe depression, suicidal ideation.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Severe tinnitus distress (THI 76-72, TFI 88-80), difficulty hearing, significant psychological impact requiring hospitalization.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Looking forward to a 'cure' and relief from the constant tinnitus.

history.present_illness: First presentation with right ear tonal tinnitus, vertigo with emesis, and sudden hearing loss attributed to weight loss.
history.noise_exposure_history: Significant factory and motorcycle noise exposure.
history.prior_management: None listed prior to this visit.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild-to-moderate sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) with asymmetrically worse hearing in the right ear.

numeric_results.Left_Ear_Configuration: Within normal limits to mild loss

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech results consistent with audiogram; no reported difficulty in noise.

numeric_results.Right_WRS: 100% at high level (red text cut off), 70% at 50 dB

tests.name: Tinnitus Assessment
tests.key_findings: Tinnitus pitch-matched to 6.5 kHz. Complete maskability.

tests.name: Immittance
tests.key_findings: Normal tympanometry but absent acoustic reflexes bilaterally.

history.present_illness: Returned 1 year later. Diagnosed with Meniere's Disease (MD). Vestibular symptoms burned out. Tinnitus became severe.
history.medical_psych_history: Admitted to hospital for psychiatric monitoring due to suicidal ideation. Depression screening (Beck) initially 10, improved to 3 (normal) after 1 month.
history.prior_management: Referred to ENT (diagnosed MD via eCochG). Psychiatric admission. Progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) instruction.
history.patient_goals: Desperate for relief; looking for a cure.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear progressed to flat, moderately severe SNHL. Left ear shows moderate low-frequency loss rising to normal (reverse slope).

numeric_results.Left_Thresholds: Rising from approx 45 dB HL (lows) to 10 dB HL (highs)

tests.name: Tinnitus Assessment
tests.key_findings: Pitch match increased to 9 kHz. Positive residual inhibition observed.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with Meniere's Disease characterized by a progression from asymmetric high-frequency loss to a flat, moderately severe SNHL in the right ear and a low-frequency rising configuration in the left ear. Speech recognition is significantly degraded in the right ear (52%) compared to the left (90%). Tinnitus is high-pitched (9 kHz), tonal, and reactive to masking (positive residual inhibition), causing severe distress and psychological impact.
counseling_points: Your hearing loss pattern and history are consistent with Meniere's Disease, which also explains the changes in your hearing levels over the last year.
The high-pitched ringing you hear is likely related to the hearing loss in the high frequencies, potentially exacerbated by your history of noise exposure.

Although the ringing is severe, testing shows that sound therapy (masking) can provide temporary relief (residual inhibition), suggesting you are a good candidate for combination hearing aids/maskers.
We will work closely with your mental health providers to ensure you are supported while we manage the hearing and tinnitus symptoms.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is exhausted and highly anxious about the noise in their head.
You should mention the past suicidal thoughts seriously but indicate you are currently 'safe' though still desperate for a solution.
Emphasize that the dizziness has stopped (burned out), but the ringing has taken its place as the primary torture.
